Literature Review: The teaching of introductory sociology courses plays a crucial role in shaping students' understanding of the discipline and its relevance to society. This literature review examines the context, materials, and pedagogical approaches used in introductory sociology courses, with a focus on their evolution and current practices in American higher education.The context of teaching introductory sociology has undergone significant changes over the past century. Wagenaar (2004) traces the development of sociology as an academic discipline in the United States, highlighting how the introductory course has evolved to reflect changing societal concerns and theoretical perspectives. The author notes that while early courses focused primarily on social problems and reform, contemporary introductory courses aim to provide a broader overview of sociological concepts and methods.Textbooks have long been a cornerstone of introductory sociology courses, serving as both a reflection of the discipline's core content and a tool for shaping students' understanding. Keith and Ender (2004) conducted a comprehensive analysis of introductory sociology textbooks, finding that while certain core concepts remain consistent over time, there has been a notable shift towards incorporating more diverse perspectives and contemporary issues. This trend is further supported by Puentes and Gougherty (2013), who observed an increase in the inclusion of globalization and environmental topics in recent textbooks.The content and structure of introductory sociology textbooks have been subject to critique and debate within the discipline. Schweingruber (2005) argues that many textbooks present an overly simplified view of sociological theories and methods, potentially hindering students' critical thinking skills. In response to such concerns, some authors have advocated for more innovative approaches to textbook design. For instance, Henslin (2017) proposes a modular approach that allows instructors to customize course content based on their specific teaching goals and student needs.The scholarship of teaching and learning (SOTL) in sociology has provided valuable insights into effective pedagogical practices for introductory courses. Atkinson and Hunt (2008) review various active learning strategies, such as collaborative projects and service-learning, that have been shown to enhance student engagement and understanding of sociological concepts. Their findings suggest that incorporating these techniques can lead to improved learning outcomes and increased student interest in the discipline.Technology has also played an increasingly important role in the teaching of introductory sociology. Brint et al. (2008) examine the integration of online resources and multimedia content in introductory courses, finding that while these tools can enhance student learning, their effectiveness depends largely on how they are implemented by instructors. The authors emphasize the need for ongoing professional development to help faculty members effectively incorporate new technologies into their teaching practices.Assessment methods in introductory sociology courses have also evolved over time. Persell et al. (2008) analyze various approaches to evaluating student learning, including traditional exams, written assignments, and more innovative methods such as e-portfolios. Their research suggests that a diverse range of assessment techniques can provide a more comprehensive understanding of student learning and help address different learning styles.The challenge of teaching sociological theory to beginners has been a recurring theme in the literature. Halasz and Kaufman (2008) propose strategies for making abstract theoretical concepts more accessible to introductory students, such as using real-world examples and encouraging students to apply theories to their own experiences. This approach aligns with broader efforts to make sociology more relevant and engaging for students from diverse backgrounds.Recent scholarship has also focused on the importance of promoting diversity and inclusion in introductory sociology courses. Brunsma et al. (2017) argue that incorporating discussions of race, gender, and other forms of social inequality is essential for developing students' sociological imagination and preparing them for an increasingly diverse society. The authors provide recommendations for creating inclusive classroom environments and addressing sensitive topics in a thoughtful and respectful manner.In conclusion, the teaching of introductory sociology has evolved significantly over time, reflecting broader changes in the discipline and in higher education. While textbooks remain an important resource, there is growing recognition of the need for diverse pedagogical approaches that engage students actively in the learning process. As the discipline continues to evolve, ongoing research and reflection on teaching practices will be crucial for ensuring that introductory sociology courses remain relevant and effective in preparing students for the complexities of contemporary society.
